frame.name: Asymmetric_reciprocality
frame.definition: <def-root>Perspective on Reciprocality in which <fen>Protagonist_1</fen> acts on or is related to <fen>Protagonist_2</fen>. The relation or event is construed as asymmetrical, inasmuch as <fen>Protagonist_1</fen> is presented as more agentive, if agency is involved (such as in conversation, participating), and <fen>Protagonist_2</fen> is presented as more passive. In cases of comparison or other relations (e.g. resembling, being near), <fen>Protagonist_2</fen> is construed as suitable as a reference for <fen>Protagonist_1</fen>, often because <fen>Protagonist_2</fen> is more temporally stable and/or is more salient and widely known.</def-root>

FE.name: Protagonist_1
FE.definition: <def-root>The profiled participant in a reciprocal event, encoded as the subject of an active-form sentence or as a by-PP in a passive. <ex>"<fex name="Protagonist_1">You</fex> can't <t>argue</t> politics with foreigners," sighed the policeman.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Protagonist_2
FE.definition: <def-root>The participant involved (subordinately) with <fen>Protagonist_1</fen> in a reciprocal event. It is generally coded in a with-PP. <ex>We have been <t>arguing</t> the point <fex name="Protagonist_2">with the inspector at claims branch</fex> for many many months and we just seem to go round in circles.</ex> </def-root>
